p.s: The film The Hate U Give really opened my eyes about some things.
The lovestory hasn't had a huge impact on me because it is shown in a lot of teenage dramas.
The special thing about this movie is that you can learn very much about racism.
I'm white so it's interesting and new (and shocking!) to me to watch a black teenage girl growing up in americaAmerica.
In my childhood I haven't even thought about what I have to do when I get in a conflict with a cop.
Starr has to experience a lot of discriminating things while growing up.
It seems like these experiences have an impact on everything else in her life: her family, her friendships and her relationship.
It is important as a white priviligedprivileged person to be aware of stories like Starr's and to listen to them.
A scene in a movie that I will probably not forget any soon is the one in which Starr's little brother helds the gun and points it on the cops to protect his family.
That scene holds a lot of power and has a big meaning behind it.
It shows how the injustice and racism affects children and how they automatically give it back to society when they're older.
